data.title: Thomas: Meaning Origin Variants
data.meta_description: What does the surname Turner-Thomas mean? Where does it come from and what are the variants of Turner-Thomas? Which famous people have the surname Turner-Thomas?
data.text:
Turner-Thomas: What does the surname Turner-Thomas mean?

Turner-Thomas is a hyphenated surname. The two separate parts derive from the English and Welsh traditions respectively. The surname Turner originates from England and is occupational, referring to someone who works with a lathe, turning wood, metal or another material. The name Thomas, on the other hand, is of Welsh origin and means 'twin.' This name was popular in the Middle Ages due to the well-known Christian figure, Saint Thomas Becket. The hyphenation of surnames often indicates a joining of two families through marriage or can be a personal choice to honor both sides of a person's ancestry. So, Turner-Thomas could denote a connexion with English professional ancestry (perhaps in wood or metal work) and Welsh lineage. However, it is crucial to recognize that the specific significance of a hyphenated surname can differ greatly depending on the personal and familial history of those bearing it.

Order DNA origin analysis

Turner-Thomas: Where does the name Turner-Thomas come from?

The Turner-Thomas surname is a largely Anglo-Irish last name which is most commonly found in the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as the United States. As a result of many Irish emigrants heading to the United States in the 18th and 19th centuries, the Turner-Thomas surname can be found in many records of old Irish American families.

The United States has the highest population of Turner-Thomas individuals, with the last name primarily found in the southern states. It is quite common in the states of Alabama, Texas, Georgia, Mississippi, Michigan, and Louisiana. Florida also has a notable population of Turner-Thomas people. Some individuals with the Turner-Thomas surname can also be found in parts of Canada, as well as Australia and New Zealand.

Today, the Turner-Thomas surname is still quite popular, with a number of families bearing the surname, though it is not as widespread as some other surnames. As an Anglo-Irish surname, it is mostly associated with people from a Celtic or Gaelic background, though it has now been adopted by many people from different backgrounds, in various parts of the world.

Variations of the surname Turner-Thomas

Turner-Thomas is a combination surname that is formed by joining two different surnames. The individual surnames from which this combination originates are ‘Turner’ and ‘Thomas’.

The surname ‘Turner’ has many different spellings and variants, including Tornor, Tornur, Tournier, Tuebor, and Thoumeau. It is a German name that originated from the Middle Ages and was an occupational name for a metal worker who worked with a lathe or forge.

The surname ‘Thomas’ also has various variants and spellings, including Thomassen, Thomason, Thoms, Thomes, Thon, and Thomaz. It is a name of Aramaic origin that first came into use during the medieval period and was derived from the Hebrew biblical name ‘Tovma’ meaning twin.

Individual surnames of Turner-Thomas include Thomer, Thomast, Turnast, Turnith, Turnth, Thorn, and Thomastown.Surnames related to Turner-Thomas are Turnball, Turnbough, Turns, Thompkins, Thomerly, Thomasson, and Thomason.

Therefore, common variants, spellings, and surnames related to Turner-Thomas are Tornor, Tornur, Tournier, Tuebor, Thomassen, Thomason, Thoms, Thomes, Thon, Thomaz, Thomer, Thomast, Turnast, Turnith, Turnth, Thorn, Thomastown, Turnball, Turnbough, Turns, Thompkins, Thomerly, Thomasson, and Thomason.
